titleStmt.title: M1-8, 1 of 10. [The great Elizabethan house, Penshurst...]. Holograph. In [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 60-76. 9p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8. 1 of 8. [The great Elizabethan house, Penshurst...]. Holograph. In [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 60-76. 9p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: If we could see the great house as it was when in the in the time of , we should see tracks, leading fro raying out to farms, & to cottages, to & barns. We should see it like a green oasis in the middle of a desert. The [close?] It was It it was [meaning?] If of the great house were to [detect?] the enemy that it should the enemy, [man?] that there should was be armour in the church: to fight against hunger in winter there should be grain in the barn. The common fight linked the great house to the small. It is that connection that is detailed in so many between master & man that is seen detail detailed so painfully & minutely in the medieval account books, inventories, that is so minutely & painfully revealed in the innumerable in the letters: it makes the staple of medieval correspondence. But there was also the other connection – there was the common belief: that bond between the great house & the small has been obli covered over. Just as the antiquaries, so that like the pilgrims way, which is oldtrack road under the hill, now along which we are once trod by [regular?] the rode to

No one uses it now. But in the when came to , that track led from the great house to the hovel. They believed In the spring they danced round the maypole; in summer at midsummer the bon fire was lit on the hill; at harvest time the waggons were crowned: at Christmas the mummers & the wassailers sung under the windows: Long They rem believed Beneath the the tree Summer Spring & summer & winter were gods. The sea was a god, the earth a goddess. This ancient belief lay beneath the Christian belief; & there was still in being the old Pagan was still in being; the old Eight gods were the Pagan Gods were still in the fields to be worshipped alive to be [remembered?], to be worshipped. And Even if the Christian faith had And Even of the Gods were losing their fervor, thewe was the Even if the service of the Pagan gods was losing its authority, there was still & even the names of the Pagan gods were slowly sinking into forgetfulness, there remained the desire, when spring came, to put on the the des desire remained to when spring came after the winter, or in the cold of Christmas, to slip off the hours of work; to make cease, for one day only, from the daily work; to be enact, to represent, to make something which had no use or give shape to the old^ which connection with the daily fight struggle, to impersonate, to draw up to become, for one day, a the thing that was b belief in person, to represent in make a to make with ones own body a symbol of the to bring out, to le leap [illeg] be into the air light, the decked up presentation of those log, of laughter, of to dance & sing, to

p.sup: still showed the scholars tell us, in the E (Elizabethan) common mind.
were [remembered?] under the semblance of the Christian one
to celebrate the common instinct, to

div.p:
to embody in any own [hinon?] the beliefs, & fear, & the which was so strong then, in the when the so much depended on the sun; when so little was known. The scholars tell us that how this double instinct all through the the middle ages this belief, this desire middle ages the roads were thus, as the sholar (scholar) tell us the down that that sunk in road, the that track of ancient belief, lay between the great house & the cottage. In the noble, as in the peasant, a half spoken anonymous voice murmured of old Gods, of old devils; of what moved propitiate, what moved of of what the well & the tree were still haunted. And, as the scholars tell us, both nobles & peasants imp feeling with the same need of something to embody this
[illeg.], the same need of a something to express the lal hang the same need of
expression of embodiment, of dance, of song. Every Down the roads along the roads from town to town, from great house to great house, came the wandering minstrels, the rhymers, the mummers, the jugglers, the bear leader. Because they shipped the Even the King & Queen must have their [after?] song makers attached to them. The Even though, [present?] ably handles because the al actor displays his body, the action the art of the mummer the actors trade was depend, partly too because there there was the [commentation?] [urges?], to dance is beyond the pale, & h sees the sees the pageant [virulently?] mocking, the actors were a despised, they were necessary. Even the churchmen, anxious as they were that homage was being paid to another God than theirs, could not suppress them; or all they could do was to divert the [illeg.] stream of current to merriment turn the uses make the

p.sup: some one who could express, embody, give voice to the hidden instinct

div.p: irrepressible instinct forms flow into miracle regular channels players & these form their But to confine – to & to induce the rhymers & the mummers, the jugglers & the bear leaders to put off their pagan leaves, their bells, their [moblets?], & robe themselves in the service of the Christian God.

That was the other bond between the great house & the cottage. For though the great, with their with their acga speaking French as easily as English, with their Latin & greek tags on their tongues, despised the must despise the jargon of the peasant, they shared the superstitions. An old woman in a cott hovel was to the King himself even, the [venal?] of an unclean spirit. A dun chicken, she said, sucked on her chin. When the were applied to her, she confessed on all Hallows E'en last she with 200 witches had gone to sea, each one in a [riddle?] a sieve drinking & making merry till they came to the Kerk of in where they landed & danced a reel. When the died a witch was [illeg.] in the corner of his room. She confessed how she had thrown a cat into the sea & raised a storm that had sunk the Kings ships.

The great house, then, when the nobles read the aloud, was connected with the village by these superstitions, needs, beliefs. himself heard the rhymers & the impudent bards. It was at He saw, at in , the Green man. It was said that he was present at the pageant, in wh queen played before Q in 15– . It was an a revival – already time had given their customs curiosity, a standing against the [past?] For already the other house was being built.

p.sup:
jugglers, [rhymers?], & sacred trees, & holy wells; & mummers
Wanton bardes & Rhymers impudent.

div.p: There is an entry in diary, which Henslowe in had jotted down in his diary the cost of the lathe, the nails, the timber that he had bought. For painting the theatre and for the clothes worn by the play Hens– that was the house that the playhouse was being built on the Banks of the Thames.

But how far was the author playwright in 1570 separate from the minstrel, the ballad singer? The past seems to be that, when Spenser Attached his name to the , the author of left his work gu unsigned This is a sign of the that there were two publics: the reading, & the playgoing. There is a division It marks a distinction between two kinds of writer – two methods, too two attitudes of mind. If there had been no minstrel, would English literature had remained a read, a book literature? No stage, no common art; but always one book to be read, privately; –

After that I had accomplished & published divers histories... many noble & divers semblances of this realm of England came &
demainded me many & ofttimes – " wrote in the preface to the ... why he "to
represent the history of the said noble King & conqueror & of the Knights with the history of the & of the death o ending of the said Arthur"

Here in the Six 7 the 21 books of the is the belief which was we have the belief of the
preserve, even what lay beneath: the Elizabe It is here we th that we tap the the fount deep reservoir we tap what lay beneath the Chaucer peasant & the noble; what beneath Spenser – the
deep reservoir of hardy old belief stories Even in the 19th century a peasant said "

It is a In pages we It is in Malorys pages that we hear the anonymous half conscious voice of it telling his tales to the noble & the peasant: reminding them of the very old Kings & Knights who lived went their ways through the wild woods seeking adventure. When [illeg.] that never lived, the noble advised him that sm ([someone?]) cd. (could) see skull at & at "in other places sword & many other things." The book itself [fulfils?] to to to this double is part In the book itself the dream is mixed with reality. It is half fable, half fact. So In We The book separates scepticism & the nobles faith. It is half fable, half fact. Now fam

There is , there is the . But at casts his enchartments, turns herself into a stone; & the English roads are but Knights are riding the roads; the roads lead to castles where Knights lie [illeg.]; the Four Queens pace on white mules; the a ship with silver sails down to the water: the Morgan le Fay turns herself to stone; the hand rises from the lake holding . Is it a child's story? No, for the The candour is like a child's; yet it is not a story told to children. There is evil in the word; love; & gr sorrow. It tells a The story is the story that we tell. we tell. But the proportions are different. There is no perspective. The It has not our perspective There is repetition; catalogue; dream; The [illeg.] is very [tableau?]. Like children, the Kings The catalogue is made after a childs particularity. And this, Bit this is the clear eye that sees so definitively; & the without exaggeration. For there is a this limpid [disclosure?] of what was real; there is no [sune?] & the [pictaugue?]; & the beauty is the in the object, not in the writers manipulations "

61"– so he went in & looked searched from chamber to chamber, & found her bed, but she was not there; there Balin looked into a fair little garden, & under a laurel tree he saw her lie under a [street?] of green samite, & a Knight with her & under their heads grass & herbs"...
79 Then the King looked about the wood...
It is but a childs world; it is a world before the self consciousness had added any mirror. There are men & women

angular, gigantic; freed from something impure; yet old; sin tarnishedl corruptL in the middle of the fresh, innocent landscape, remembering;– par It To follow the Knights & ladies in this strange pre-historic England is to lose our beags (bearings); to shed many habits of thoughtl but we after all this it is not an imprinted fabricated world; it is behind us still, deep down; & savage, primitive, still existing ending

But Of the writer, nothing is known. He does not exist apart from his book. It is like the anonymous voice speaking anonymously; the voice of a very old yet still still common world, where the story is already known to the listener, where the listener the listener the voice of an unknown man, who has been travelling in strange parts, & comes to the door, across the marsh, through the flood, to remind the noble & the peasant of what he has heard long ago.

In the great house & in the cottage this half articulate anonymous voice murmured of old Gods, & Kings, & Knights & Ladies. The well & the tree were still haunted. the traveller tell XVII that about noon, or about midnight, when the moon is full & shining, they often see an assay of hawkers with dogs & sound of horses, who, in answer to the [enquiries?] say that they are of the [homestead?] & fellowship of Arthur." Along the roads from town to town, from one great house to another came the [mummers?] & the rhymers, the jugglers the bear leaders, the speakers of ballads, the fo while for these who could read it & hear it,
book told the story of .

Then, the instinct to enact, to impersonate what they see heard came into being. Even the King & Queen must have their minstrels to give shape to this hidden instinct. The author was [special?]: the for he displayed his body: after, because, feeling himself an outcast, he used the outsiders prvilge (privilege) to of irresponsible mockery. Yet just as we isolate those who say what we are too proud to admit, the minstrel was tolerated. Even the churchmen, aware that the other gods than his were being worshipped, mus could not suppress the actor. When he was no longer If they could, they constrained the juggler & the dancer to put off their leaves & their bells & to robe themselves as the [pilgrimages?] in a miracle play. But when the old pl story relgios (religious) story was stale, they left played in the [courtyard? churchyard?], & at last set up their pageant in the market place.
, it is said, was a with among the audience at one of these old pageants. He noted
